data.title: Automatically insert line breaks in git commit messages

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm trying to get into the habit of writing good commit messages. Not sure if this should be the default but it would be really useful if vscode automatically wrapped commit message lines at say 80 chars and inserted line breaks.

I don't mean changing the appearance of the text in the commit message box, just before it's actually committed. The line length could be in an option too.

data.title: "Define Keybindings" is invalidating keybindings.json
data.body:
After adding a new keybinding using the "Define Keybinding" button, the JSON array in keybindings.json becomes invalid due to lack of a comma between keybinding objects.

https://gfycat.com/SelfassuredUntimelyHound

data.title: Debug console does not handle newlines in DebugProtocol.EvaluateResponse correctly.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am using the  0.10.6 (December) release of VS Code and building a debug adapter. When returning strings with newlines (\n) in the body.result of a DebugProtocol.EvaluateResponse the result printed in the debug console has literal \n strings shown instead of printing on multiple lines.

Example:

Returning this

response.body = {
            result: 'ABC\n123',
            variablesReference: 0
};

Should print 

ABC
123

on the debug console. Instead it prints

ABC\n123

data.title: Breakpoints don't work in remote attach
data.body:
I tested everything and it works perfectly in webstorm but visual code will not hit certain areas.  Even if I play around with adding them after attach.  

Secondly there is no way to know the scripts the debugger is attached to.  

Essentially this is not ready for public consumption.

-RJ

data.title: High Contrast Support
In the Replace window tab from Find goes to Replace. Shift-tab from Replace goes to Close
data.body: I do a lot of navigation with my keyboard and find myself constantly closing find and replace. It can be really frustrating when I have typed out a long string of regex in find because upon opening it again the find field is trimmed/erased. I am not sure if this is intentional or not but it doesn't seem intuitive at all.

data.title: Add -d --diff switch to open two files in diff view
data.body:
I wanted to use VSCodes diff view for the Perforce source control I am using. In this case it allows to call third party tools for the diff view. At the moment I launch it with command line arguments to open those two files (modified client and the original depot file) and than manually select both working items and compare them to each other. 
I realize it might be very useful overall to add a -d or --diff %f1 %f2 switch to the launch option of vscode to launch Visual Studio Code immediately in the diff view.

Example
`code --diff original.cpp modified.cpp` (vscode launches immediately in the diff view for those two files

data.title: Ctrl + Click navigating to files outside of the project folder does not work
data.body:
I am using VSCode to open and work with a single folder within a much larger, and older project.

I use script tags to reference js files which are much higher up the folder structure. I use relative paths for this.
When I ctrl + click on the src of one of these script tags, VSCode removes any relative path "../../" information and then appends the remaining path onto the end of my current working folder path.
the result is that the file is not found.

Using files outside of the project folder works fine in every other way, including intellisense and code completion, so I would expect the Ctrl + Click behaviour to work.

**Relative path example**
Working folder: C:\development\trunk\myproject\newstuff\
`<script src="../../modules/test.js">`
This file is at: C:\development\trunk\modules\test.js
VSCode tries to find it at: C:\development\trunk\myproject\newstuff\modules\test.js

**Absolute Path Example**
Working folder: C:\development\trunk\myproject\newstuff\
`<script src="C:\development\trunk\modules\test.js">`
VSCode tries to find it at: C:\development\trunk\myproject\newstuff\C:\development\trunk\modules\test.js

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/344675/12813747/e6f666f0-cb31-11e5-99bb-eae501b403e1.png)

data.title: Provide an option to disable fuzzy matching in file picker

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The new fuzzy file picker makes it really hard to me to find files in huge projects (~5,000 source files). Regardless of what I'm typing in the file picker I receive a lot of results I definitely don't want. Example below:

![fuzzyfilepicker](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3448684/12812691/b717e3da-cb33-11e5-8fa8-43488987fbc5.png)

The old file picker used to work like the IntelliSense widget which feels consistent to me as a user. Is there a way to turn on the old file picker again?

data.title: "Close All Files" action can leave the editor area stale and broken
data.body:
When having more than one file open, running "Close All Files" or the newly added "Close Other Files" can leave the editor area in a broken state.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/12812742/15f75188-cb34-11e5-9f65-8abf2eec446d.png)

data.title: vscode does not seem to support mixed source map locations
data.body:
I have a vscode project using TypeScript with tests compiling to the /test path and module source files being output to a /release path. I'm using gulp to generate source maps.
If I specify a launch.json configuration with sourceMaps: true and an outDir of 'release' I am able to set breakpoints for the module source files, but breakpoints do not work for the tests.
If I remove the outDir path, vscode looks for source maps next to the files and I am able to step through the tests but breakpoints do not work in the module code.
I've tried compiling the module code to the path containing the source, but vscode only seems to use the first path it finds for source maps.

I would expect vscode to use the outDir path, but fall back to looking for map files next to the source - or better yet, as specified by the sourceMappingURL comment.

Interestingly, if I step from the tests with outDir unspecified, vscode can locate the source maps and step through the module code. It just doesn't stop at the initial breakpoint in the module code unless the outDir property is set.

Related to #2490, #1923.

data.title: Test omnisharp installation hint
data.body:
### Assignment
- [x] Windows @stevencl 
- [x] OS X @chrisdias 
- [x] Linux @weinand 
### Details

We plan to make omnisharp an optional extension. To make a smooth transition we let the user know once and offer a direct install. 
- have no omnisharp installed
- open vs code, open any  csharp-ish resource (`*.cs, project.json, *.csproj` etc)
- you are informed and offered to install

Make sure
- that you get a reasonable hint
- the hint only shows once (check local store for `global://extensionsAssistant/legacy...`)
- you can install omnisharp from the hint

data.title: Go back and forward keyboard shortcut does not work sometimes

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body: Sometimes when I start VSCode the go back and forward short cuts doesn't work. Though, clicking on the menu bar works. Though the icons are gone some times as well.

data.title: CSS not syntax highlighted or auto-complete in SVG like it is in HTML
data.body:
Not sure if this is covered by  #728 as there is no description.

In HTML the CSS highlighting and Intelisense is applied when CSS inside the style element. However, in SVG it is just treated as regular text content.

data.title: [themes] JS broken with Dark and light (Visual Studio) themes
Should the js scope also be added to jsx files?
data.body: Currently using the language mode JavaScript React adds `jsx` and `ts` scopes globally but not `js`. This means styles created specifically for JavaScript will not be applied to JavaScript React.

data.title: [JavaScript] Functions calls should be scoped
data.body:
A lot of themes want to color function calls in JavaScript. Here are some examples:

``` js
console.log(); // log should be highlighted
foo();         // foo should be highlighted
foo.bar();     // bar should be highlighted
```

Not sure the best scope for these, perhaps `entity.function.name`?

_Created from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2684_

data.title: [JavaScript] 'window' and 'console' should have 'support.class' scope
data.body:
The [OceanicNext tmTheme](http://tmtheme-editor.herokuapp.com/#!/editor/url/https://raw.githubusercontent.com/voronianski/oceanic-next-color-scheme/master/Oceanic%2520Next.tmTheme) ([homepage](http://labs.voronianski.com/oceanic-next-color-scheme/)) colors `window` and `console` yellow using the scope `support.class`.

_Created from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2684_

data.title: [JavaScript] 'from' should have 'keyword.operator' scope
data.body:
The [OceanicNext tmTheme](http://tmtheme-editor.herokuapp.com/#!/editor/url/https://raw.githubusercontent.com/voronianski/oceanic-next-color-scheme/master/Oceanic%2520Next.tmTheme) ([homepage](http://labs.voronianski.com/oceanic-next-color-scheme/)) colors `from` as teal using the scope `keyword.operator`.

_Created from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2684_

data.title: [JavaScript] 'this', 'super' and 'default' should have 'variable.language' scope
data.body:
The [OceanicNext tmTheme](http://tmtheme-editor.herokuapp.com/#!/editor/url/https://raw.githubusercontent.com/voronianski/oceanic-next-color-scheme/master/Oceanic%2520Next.tmTheme) ([homepage](http://labs.voronianski.com/oceanic-next-color-scheme/)) colors `this`, `super` and `default` as red and italic using the scope `variable.language`.

_Created from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2684_

data.title: CSS value auto complete behaviour applies less frequently
data.body:
(not sure how to title this bug/feature)

Previously when you had typed a CSS property (e.g. "motion-path: " it would display the auto-complete list for all the CSS values after pressing space.

In the insider build, if you press space nothing happens. It only starts giving completions if you know a character in the value so that it starts matching hits. The previous behaviour was IMO better as it allowed you to see all the hits without looking up what the valid values are, and without having to read documentation to find out what the shortcut is.

Also, when you press the ctrl+space shortcut after typing the property (e.g. motion-path:[ctrl+space]) it suggests "no suggestions" rather than giving the list. So you have to type space then ctrl+space to get the list.

I'm not sure if this behaviour is a regression, or purposely chosen updated behaviour, but I think it is less discoverable now (and personally on Mac I rarely use ctrl shortcuts except for ctrl3 for #)

data.title: Atom.io like multiline support for snippets
